physdesc.extent: (85 boxes, 2 record cartons, 39 flat boxes, 2 shoe boxes, and 10 sound recording boxes)

did.abstract: Among his many roles on stage, screen and television in a career that spanned sixty years, American comedian and dancer Ray Bolger was best known for his role as the Scarecrow in the 1939 film, The Wizard of Oz. In addition to his work in film and television, he continually returned to the stage, often appearing in one-man shows. The collection consists of script material, contracts, clippings, correspondence, photographs, music, and ephemera related to Bolger's lengthy career.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.
Processed by Lauren Jung with assistance from Vanessa Villavicencio, Michele James, Alexandra Apolloni, and Julie Graham, 2013.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Raymond Wallace Bolger was born on January 10, 1904, in Dorchester, Massachusetts. As a teenager, he danced on street corners in Boston and began his acting career performing in amateur theatricals. He made his stage debut with the Bob Ott Musical Comedy Repertory Company in 1922 and was soon appearing in vaudeville with Gus Edwards. Not long after, he appeared in Broadway productions of By Jupiter, George White's Scandals, Keep Off the Grass, Life Begins at 8:40, and On Your Toes, in which he won praise for his dancing skills in a number choreographed by George Balanchine. In time, he began appearing in musical films such as The Great Ziegfeld, Rosalie, Sunny, Sweethearts, and his most well-known film, The Wizard of Oz. During World War II, he helped organize U.S.O. shows that toured American military and naval bases around the world.

In 1948, he returned to Broadway and starred in a three-year run of Where's Charley, which catapulted his stage career and lead to a film version of the story, starring Bolger, in 1952. That same year Bolger made his television debut with The Colgate Comedy Hour, and from 1953-1955 he starred in his own television show The Ray Bolger Show on ABC. Originally titled Where's Raymond in the first season, the show cast Bolger as Raymond Wallace, a Broadway star living in suburbia. Bolger and his wife Gwen were the owners of their own production company, B&R Enterprises, which produced Where's Raymond/The Ray Bolger Show. In 1957, he starred in Washington Square and made numerous guest appearances on television shows, such as Hollywood Palace, The Jimmy Durante Show, The Judy Garland Show, and The Red Skelton Hour. During this time, he continued to work in motion pictures, appearing in films such as April in Paris, Babes in Toyland, and The Runner Stumbles. In between his work in film and television, Bolger continued to perform on the stage, appearing in one-man shows and song-and-dance concerts as well as stage musicals such as All American, Come Summer, and The Happy Time.

Bolger was involved with a number of philanthropic causes, including the American Red Cross and the American Heart Association, and in political advocacy, appearing and performing at numerous events. He was also an avid golfer, often competing in celebrity tournaments; and he was also involved in various business ventures, including real estate. Ray Bolger died of cancer on January 15, 1987 in Los Angeles, California.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of material related to the career of comedian, dancer, and actor Ray Bolger. Included in the collection is script material, contractual documents, correspondence, clippings, photographs, music, and ephemera related to Bolger's career. Notably absent are original materials relating to the production of the 1939 film Wizard of Oz.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Arranged in the following series:
Biographical and Personal
Television Projects
Motion Picture Projects
Stage Projects
Radio Projects
Audio Recording and Short Film Projects

Armed Services Entertainment
Appearances and Events
Unidentified Projects
Correspondence
Photographs
Clippings
Ephemera
Awards, Honors, and Certificates
Business, Financial, and Legal
Music
Scrapbooks
Writings By or About Bolger
Publications

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Personal and Biographical series is a small amount of personal documents relating to Bolger. This includes biographical and personal documents, a trunk inventory, and planners/day log books. For more biographical information, see the series Writings By or About Bolger.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Television Projects mainly represents Wheres Raymond and/or The Ray Bolger Show. Included are scripts and legal documents such as TV rerun sheets, contracts, and music clearances. Additionally, there are scripts documenting Bolgers appearances on a variety of popular television programs such as Battlestar Galactica, Diff'rent Strokes, The Entertainer, General Electric Theater, The Hollywood Palace, The Partridge Family and a small amount of publicity, production information, treatments, outlines, correspondence, clippings, and photographs. See the Music Series for orchestral parts that appear to be from The Ray Bolger Show. The series is arranged alphabetically by projects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The series includes a small amount of scripts, publicity, correspondence, film stills, and clippings related to film projects in which Bolger was associated. Films represented include: April in Paris, Babes in Toyland, The Great Ziegfeld, Roaslie, The Runner Stumbles, Sunny, Thats Dancing, Two of a Kind, and Where's Charley?. Notably absent are original materials relating to the production of the 1939 film The Wizard of Oz except for a very small number of clippings, sheet music, and a facsimile copy of a cast and crew contact list. The series is arranged alphabetically by project.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Stage Projects series consists of material documenting Bolgers work in the theater, club appearances, and concerts. Projects represented include productions such as All American, By Jupiter, Come Summer, On Your Toes, Wheres Charley and live appearances at the Empire Room at the Waldorf Astoria and numerous Las Vegas engagements. Included are scripts, contracts, fan mail, clippings, and a small amount of publicity, ephemera, and photographs. The series is arranged alphabetically by project.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The bulk of the Unidentified Projects series are scripts which are not identified with known projects, and which may have been submitted to Bolger for his consideration, and which may or may not have been produced. Additionally there is a small amount of writings that appear to be sketches, bits, ideas, lyrics, synopses, treatments, and titled and untitled stories. Also included is a small number of files collated by the processor containing holographic notes which may have been written by Ray and/or Gwen Bolger. There is no specific arrangement to the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series is letters and notes sent to Ray Bolger and/or his wife Gwen Bolger, and is mostly fan mail addressed to Bolger. Also included is correspondence between the Bolgers during WWII, letters or notes to Bolger from notable entertainment and political figures, and personal correspondence from the Bolgers friends and family. There is a very small amount of items related to members of Gwen Bolgers family, the Rickards. The majority of the series is arranged chronologically by decade. Correspondence related to specific projects may be found in the Motion Picture Projects, Stage Projects, Television Projects, and Unidentified Projects series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Photographs series contains images documenting Bolgers long career in the entertainment indudsty. Included are publicity stills and headshots of Bolger, some identified as MGM, RKO, or ABC productions; photographs of Bolger with other performers and/or public figures; and photographs of Bolger at unidentified functions he attended and/or in which he performed, including golf events, and what appear to be USO-related appearances. Also included are what appear to be personal and publicity photographs of Ray and/or Gwen Bolger, as well as other unidentified individuals. The series is arranged alphabetically by file titles reflecting the contents of each folder. Additional photographs relating to specific projects may be found in the, Motion Picture Projects, Stage Projects, Television Projects, and Unidentified Projects series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Clippings series a mixture of publicity and promotional write-ups about appearances and events in which Bolger was involved and articles written about Bolger, often referencing his role in the Wizard of Oz. There are also a small number of items pertaining to Gwen Bolger. The series is arranged alphabetically by file titles reflecting the contents of each folder. General clippings about Bolger are listed first. Clippings related to specific projects may be found in the, Motion Picture Projects, Stage Projects, Television Projects, and Unidentified Projects series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Ephemera series consists of advertising ephemera; publications mentioning or featuring Bolger; programs, playbills, and/or ephemera from appearances and events Bolger may have attended; and sketches and drawings of Bolger in and out of character, some depicting him as the Scarecrow. Additionally there is a small amount of business cards and entertainment publications that do not appear to be related to Bolger.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The series consists of award and honor certificates bestowed upon Bolger from a wide range of organizations, clubs, orders, and associations, including an honorary degree from the University of Connecticut. Also included are membership cards and certificates for various clubs and organizations. There is no specific arrangement to the series.

Series 16. Business, Legal, and Financial Records

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Business, Legal, and Financial records consist mainly of contracts and financial documents representing a variety of projects in which Bolger was involved throughout his career. Included are agreements with studios such as CBS, KNBC, and NBC, commercial companies, and live venue locations such as Cocoanut Grove and Hotel Sahara, among others. Of note are a photocopy of Bolgers agreement from July 1939 with respect to commercial tie-ups of Wizard of Oz properties and a copy of the term agreement Bolger had with MGM in April of 1936. The financial documents reflect the operations of B&R Enterprises and other business ventures. The series is arranged alphabetically by file titles reflecting the contents of each folder. A small number of contracts regarding specific projects may be found in the Motion Picture Projects, Stage Projects, Television Projects, and Unidentified Projects series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Music series consists of printed music sheets, songbooks, commercial sheet music, orchestral parts, vocal parts, and handwritten music sheets. Included is music representing All American, Babes in Toyland, Come Summer, On Your Toes, Sunny, Washington Square, and Wheres Charley?, among others; some items are untitled. Additionally, there are orchestral parts and arrangements which may represent the television program, The Ray Bolger Show. The series is arranged alphabetically by song title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Scrapbooks contain newspaper clippings docurmenting projects and performances from Bolgers early stage career. Additionally, there are scrapbooks from the IBM Golden Circle (1965 and 1979) and the University of Connecticut Honorary Degree ceremony. There is no specific arrangement to this series.

did.unittitle: Black scrapbook of early vaudeville career

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Mostly George White's Scandals clippings.

Series 19. Writings By or About Bolger

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The series consists of printed and holographic writings by, about, an submitted to Bolger. Included are scripts, magazine articles, eulogies, and holographic notes. There is no specific arrangement to this series.
